title: Market Recap: Friday, March 5: Stocks closed higher at the end of a choppy trading day
text: Stocks turned mixed in a choppy trading day after the Labor Department's February jobs report handily exceeded expectations, reaffirming the building momentum in the economic recovery, but also stoking a rise in Treasury yields and concerns over an economic overheating. The S&P 500 rose intraday, and the Dow gained in choppy trading.

title: Inflation Caused by Fed Dismissing Concerns as Transient: Summers
text: Mar.05 -- Former U.S. Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, a Wall Street Week contributor, says that every great inflation is caused by a central bank that dismisses it as transient.

title: Stocks: Dips are a good time to put capitol to work: US Bank Wealth Management CIO
text: Yahoo Finance's Seana Smith and Adam Shapiro spoke to U.S. Bank Wealth Management CIO Eric Freedman about bond markets and the latest outlook for stocks as the February jobs report crushed expectations.

title: Why SPACs are booming in 2021
text: SPAC, which stands for special purpose acquisition company, is surging in 2021. From January to February there have been $70 billion dollars in SPAC transactions.

title: Interest Rates Are Most Uncertain of All Forecasts: Tyson
text: Mar.05 -- Former Council of Economic Advisers Chair Laura Tyson says that interest rates carry the greatest uncertainty of all forecasts. Northern Trust Wealth Management CIO Katie Nixon thinks that strong fundamentals suggest a big second half of 2021.

title: Cramer's game plan for the trading week of March 8
text: "Mad Money" host Jim Cramer revealed what corporate earnings he will be watching for, advising investors to build up a cash position to be ready to buy stocks the next time the market sells off.

title: Jim Cramer: There will be an 'uneven' roaring boom for the U.S. economy
text: 'Mad Money Host Jim Cramer joins 'The News with Shepard Smith' to discuss jobs, the economy, and what the recent market sell-off means for investors.

title: Yield curve control explained: 10-Year yield tops 1.6% following February jobs report
text: Yahoo FInance's Brian Cheung joined Yahoo Finance Live to break down how February's jobs report is impacting the 10-year treasury note yield.

title: Cramer reacts to February jobs report: 'Just what this crazy market needed'
text: "It was a hidden-goldilocks report: a lot more people are getting hired, thanks to the vaccine rollout and the reopening, but not so many that the Fed will feel compelled to raise interest rates, and some are really being left behind," the "Mad Money" hos said.

title: Cramer's week ahead: Build a cash position for the next stock sell-off
text: "Mad Money" host Jim Cramer gave his reaction to the February jobs report and Friday's market activity, telling investors to expect more declines on the market.

title: The Reflation Trade Is Stirring Growing Pains in Growth Stocks. Here's Why.
text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average, with its bias toward big, economically sensitive companies, rose 1.8% on the week, while the more balanced S&P 500, climbed 0.8%. The Nasdaq Composite, home to high-priced growth stocks, however, tumbled 2.1%.

title: Tech rebound pulls stocks out of a slump and to weekly gain
text: Wall Street ended sharply higher after a volatile session Friday, with the Nasdaq rebounding at the end of a week that saw it extend losses to about 10 percent from its previous record high. All three main indexes bounced back from losses earlier in the day, with investors in recent sessions spooked by rising interest.

title: Wall Street Week Ahead: Investors weigh how far tech stocks can slide after volatile week
text: As U.S. technology shares stumble, investors are debating whether the decline is an opportunity to scoop up bargains or a sign of more pain to come for stocks that have led markets higher for years.

title: Liz Ann Sonders: We're in a churning phase driven by the move up in yields
text: Liz Ann Sonders, Charles Schwab chief investment strategist, joins 'Closing Bell' to discuss the move in markets. She says we're in a churning phase and likely to see more valuation resets in the market.

title: The Fed: Fed officials echo Powell's dovish message
text: Federal Reserve officials on Friday reinforced the dovish message Fed Chairman Jerome Powell delivered 24 hours earlier.

title: Markets Close On Positive Note After Turbulent Week
text: To quote the classic Dinah Washington tune: What a difference a day makes. After the markets tumbled Thursday amid rising bond yields and Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's prediction of increasing inflation, markets closed Friday on an upswing fueled by the positive news of 379,000 jobs added in February.

title: Fmr. head of Square Capital Jackie Reses discusses SPAC market
text: Jackie Reses, CEO of Post House Capital, joins 'Closing Bell' to discuss the SPAC market. She says SPACs are here to stay, but some fundamentals in the markets such as rising interest rates, have impacted the industry.

title: Stocks face the crosscurrents of higher interest rates and fiscal stimulus in the week ahead
text: The Covid-19 aid package is on track for final Congressional approval in the week ahead. It could be a double-edged sword for markets

title: Is Now a Good Time to Invest in the Market?
text: Many investors are panic selling right now, but you shouldn't be one of them. Pullbacks like these are a good time to invest in great stocks at discounted prices.

title: The Dow Rose 572 Points Because Stocks Surged on Good Jobs Data
text: Both growth and value stock soared on an unusually strong jobs report. The energy sector had a great day.

title: Charles Payne: Powell's comments were swan song for the market
text: FOX Business' Charles Payne, Surevest CEO Rob Luna, Kingsview Wealth Management CIO Scott Martin and Needham & Company senior internet analyst Laura Martin discuss the Federal Reserve's actions, how the markets have reacted, inflation, Big Tech stocks and investment opportunities. #FoxBusiness Subscribe to Fox News!

title: Stock Market Today: The 'Reflation Trade' Kicks Back Into High Gear
text: The Dow and Nasdaq grew farther apart on Monday, as the Senate's COVID-stimulus green light sparked another rise in interest rates and another wave of selling in tech.

title: Dow storms back 700 points, wiping away midday deficit as bond yield rates decline from session high
text: 4:15 pm: S&P 500 led by energy sector The Dow closed Friday up 571 points, 1.9%, at 31,495. The blue chip index surged more than 700 points after dipping roughly 150 points into the red around 11:30 am.

title: Stock Market Today: Tech Roller Coaster Leaves Investors Thrilled
text: Stocks, especially tech, appeared poised for yet another bloodletting on Friday despite a stellar February jobs report. Then came the turn.

title: UBS's Michael Zinn discusses sharp reversal of stocks
text: Michael Zinn, UBS financial services senior portfolio manager, says what he saw in the markets today was encouraging, since the tech and health care sectors have come back a bit. However, he warns we aren't out of the wood just yet in markets.

title: Gina Sanchez discusses why stocks are moving up despite higher rates
text: Gina Sanchez, Chantico Global CEO, says markets have been focused on valuation. She says while she's bullish on the recovery stocks, she believes some tech stocks were overvalued which explains why they've dropped so drastically in the past couple of days.

title: Higher growth rates for 2021: Economist on outlook after February jobs
text: Dana Peterson, chief economist at The Conference Board, joins 'Closing Bell' to discuss the February jobs report, her thoughts on additional stimulus and more.

title: Dr. Gottlieb: Need to provide reasonable path for activity reintroduction
text: Dr. Scott Gottlieb, former FDA commissioner, joins 'Closing Bell' to discuss the pace of the vaccine rollout and what is appropriate coronavirus etiquette after getting the vaccine.

title: Stocks climb again after stronger-than-expected jobs report — Here's what experts are watching
text: Stocks saw a major reversal on Friday after the February jobs report. Market watchers weigh in on what could come next.

title: Mortgage rates rise higher after stronger-than-expected jobs report
text: Diana Olick joins 'Closing Bell' to discuss mortgage rates, which is rising higher after Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's comments this week. The stronger-than-expected jobs report also helped with sentiment.

title: Dow jumps 572 points in wild session as investors view jobs report as good for the economy---investors keep one eye on yields
text: The U.S. stock market finished Friday sharply higher and the broad market managed a powerful rebound in a turbulent session that highlighted the choppy week that bullish investors faced amid evidence that an improving economy may drive corporate borrowing costs considerably higher, wreaking havoc on richly valued, speculative names that have enjoyed a powerful bound in the COVID-19 era. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite was on the frontlines during the period, on the brink of a correction at the conclusion of Thursday's close, the index finished 1.6% higher on Friday after notching an intrday low at 12,397.05, managing one of its biggest intraday comebacks in a year.

title: Dow soars 572 points as strong jobs report emboldens dip-buying in tech stocks
text: US stocks rebounded Friday as dip-buyers emboldened by the strong February jobs report helped lift mega-cap technology stocks out of correction territory. Businesses added 379,000 payrolls in February, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced Friday. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg expected a gain of 200,000 payrolls. Further, the US unemployment rate unexpectedly fell to 6.2% from 6.3%.

title: Is February's Strong Jobs Data Telling a Recovery Story?
text: February non-farm payroll data easily eclipsed expectations, showing 379,000 jobs added versus an expectation of around 200,000. Leisure and hospitality jobs added 355,000 to the headline number, with 285,900 being jobs at "restaurants and drinking places.

title: Energy is outperforming tech by widest margin since 2002: Paul Hickey
text: CNBC's Brian Sullivan talks about the energy trade and tech stocks with Paul Hickey of Bespoke Investment Group. title: Conference Board chief economist breaks down the February jobs report
text: Dana Peterson, chief economist at The Conference Board, joins 'Closing Bell' to discuss the February jobs report, her thoughts on additional stimulus and more.

title: Market Extra: Nasdaq staging biggest intraday comeback in over a year as stock market rebounds from Friday rout
text: In a wild trading day, the Nasdaq Composite is forging a comeback for the annals. On Friday, the technology-laden index had been down by as much as 2.6% to hit an intraday nadir at 12,397.05, as data released by the Labor Department on Friday showed that a solid recovery was under way on the jobs front.

title: 6% unemployment rate doesn't tell the whole story: Marc Morial
text: Marc Morial, former mayor New Orleans and president and CEO of National Urban League, joins 'Power Lunch' to discuss the February jobs report, the proposed stimulus bill and more.

title: Stocks turn positive after strong jobs report
text: Yahoo Finance's Jared Blikre breaks down the latest stock market news following the February Jobs Report.

title: Hiring outlook: Many people are still on the sidelines looking for work: LinkedIn Economist
text: Yahoo Finance's Aikiko Fujita and Zack Guzman spoke with Karin Kimbrough, LinkedIn Chief Global Economist about job growth and the outlook for employment.

title: Peaks and Valleys Define Volatile Week on Wall Street
text: The first week of March was a volatile one, with vaccine news, profit-taking and rising bond yields causing commotion up and down Wall Street.

title: Pullback will not give way to immediate buying opportunity, Technician says
text: Katie Stockton, Fairlead Strategies founder and managing partner, and Tim Seymour, Seymour Asset Management CIO, joins 'Power Lunch' to discuss the momentum trade and the state of the markets.

title: Rate shocks on the way for highly-levered areas of market: Ron Insana
text: Ron Insana, Schroders North America senior advisor, and Jamie Cox, Harris Financial Group managing partner, join 'Power Lunch' to discuss the momentum trade and whether it can continue to go higher with rising interest rates.

title: Robinhood chooses the Nasdaq for its IPO, sources say
text: Robinhood has chosen the Nasdaq as the exchange for its eventual initial public offering, according to sources familiar with the matter.

title: Tech Stocks Escape From Correction Territory
text: Technology stocks briefly touched “correction” territory on Friday, as the recent decline on the Nasdaq Composite extended beyond 10%. The sector has been pressured by rising interest rates.

title: Nasdaq slump badly bruises Wall St's most loved stocks
text: Thursday's Nasdaq slump briefly saw it down more than 10% from last month's record high, on the cusp of what investors consider a correction and marking the second drop of such a magnitude since September, with many of Wall Street's most loved stocks slammed hardest.

title: Insider Cannabis: Top cannabis stock picks for 2021— Chris Webber's $100 million equity fund — Atai raises $157 million
text: Welcome to Insider Cannabis, our weekly newsletter where we're bringing you an inside look at the deals, trends, and personalities driving the multibillion-dollar global cannabis boom. Sign up here to get it in your inbox every week.

title: Drilling Deep: What is trucking going to be like in 2030?
text: On this week's edition of Drilling Deep, podcast host John Kingston is joined by Ben Stanley of the IBM Institute for Business Value. The institute recently completed an update on its look at the future of trucking.

title: Is Saks Taking A Giant Leap -Backwards -By Splitting Off E-Commerce?
text: While most retailers are moving to integrate their physical and online operations, Hudson's Bay Co. is going the opposite direction with its Saks division

title: Dream Industrial: Reviewing 2020 With Perfect Hindsight
text: We have written about this REIT several times in the last year.

title: Why Ariel Investment's Bobrinskoy likes reopening stock MSGE
text: CNBC's Brian Sullivan discusses markets and stock picks with Charles Bobrinskoy of Ariel Investments and Mike Hunstad of Northern Trust Asset Management.
